elements.content: Created for the Game Dev Knights Arcade Jam. Designed to be played on an arcade cabinet. The movement of the knife is meant to match up with a normal arcade joystick. The game is playable on the UCF downtown campus arcade machines.

To create the pizza slicing mechanic, the pie is made up of 8 micro slices broken up into macro slices. When you make a cut, the system finds which macro slices are being touched by the cut, and then splits their children micro slices into the appropriate number of macro slices. If you cut a micro slice in half, all the slices to the left of the cut will go in one macro, and to the right in another. I then get the average angle of every micro slice contained, and move the macro slice a certain distance away from the center at that angle.

This gives me the behavior of the pizza parts splitting apart. Afterwards, I add a nice tweening function to the movement for polish. Below you can see the The slicing in action, with a red line drawn from the center to the calculated position. The angle of the line is determined by the angle of each micro slice contained by the portion.
